Prompt:
Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Long, long ago, there were people who lived before history was written down. These people are called prehistorians. They used tools and made their own food. Prehistorians hunted and gathered food. They lived in caves. Sometimes they made their own houses from sticks and stones. Prehistorians made their own clothes from animal skins and leaves. They had to be very strong and brave. They had to fight off wild animals. Prehistorians were very good at making things. They made their own tools and weapons. They made their own art. Sometimes they made pictures on rocks. We don’t know very much about prehistorians. But we can learn about them from their old things. We can learn about them from their old tools and pictures. A long time ago, before our time, there were people who lived. They lived before our history began. This time is called prehistory. They lived in small groups, in caves, or in houses made of sticks and mud. They hunted animals for food, and they grew plants in the ground. They used stones to make tools, like knives and spears. They used sticks to make bows and arrows. They made fire to keep warm and to cook their food. They lived in a world that was very different from the world we live in today. They didn’t have cars, or computers, or houses made of bricks. They lived in a world that was very hard to live in. But they were clever and strong. They made the best of the world they lived in. They are the people who came before us. They are the people who helped us become who we are today.

Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 150 words. 

Prehistory is the time before history. It is when our ancestors lived. They didn’t have books to write about their lives. So, we don’t know much about it. We can guess about it. We can look at the rocks, bones, and tools we find. These things help us understand what our ancestors did. Some people think that our ancestors lived in caves. Others think they lived in tents. We can guess that they hunted animals for food. We can also guess that they made tools from rocks and sticks. We can learn more about prehistory by looking at the things that our ancestors left behind. But we can never really know for sure. It’s like finding an egg in the grass. We can ask the birds and animals if it’s theirs, but they might not know. We can guess, but we can never be sure.  ​

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 150 words. 
Prehistory is a time when there was no written language. There were no books or papers. People just told each other stories. They passed down the stories from one generation to the next. People lived in small groups. They hunted animals for food. They made their own tools from rocks and sticks. They built homes from branches and leaves. There were no cities, just small villages. There were no cars or trains, just people on foot. They traveled long distances on foot. The weather was cold. They had to be careful to stay warm. They had to be careful to find food. People were very strong and brave. They had to be. They had to survive. They didn’t have any tools to help them. They just had to rely on themselves.

Note: This text will be a paragraph, but it can be broken into smaller chunks if needed for the student's reading level. The goal is to keep the text concise and engaging while using simple vocabulary and sentence structure.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 150 words. The Sun’s light shines on Earth. Our world is old. Before we were here, other people lived. That was a long time ago. It was before our history books. That time is called prehistory. People didn’t write down their stories back then. But we can still learn about them. We can look at pictures and tools they made. We can dig in the ground and find things they left behind. We can use that to learn about their lives. That way, we can know more about prehistory. People in prehistory hunted for food and built homes. They made tools and clothes. They were people just like us, but they lived a long time ago. They had their own stories and ways of life. Prehistory is a time of mystery and adventure.

The people of prehistory lived a long time ago. They didn’t have the same things we have today. They used to make tools from rocks. They hunted animals and picked fruits and berries. The people of prehistory used to live in caves. They made fires to cook their food and to keep warm. They made clothes from animal hides. The people of prehistory used to move from place to place. They followed the animals they hunted. They lived in small groups. The people of prehistory didn’t know how to write. They didn’t have houses. They didn’t have schools. But they were good at making things and taking care of themselves. They were strong and brave. They were able to live in a world that was very different from the one we have today.
